comments.commentBody: They aren't doing anything surreptitiously. They are very upfront about monetizing user content, just as Google is. It is called advertising, and is one of the largest industries in the world. There is nothing underhanded about it.

Nick, some people are deleting their Facebook accounts, and that's not the end of the world. The other alternative is to simply look past the assurances of privacy as false promises. One might only post on the assumption that everything posted will be as public as any public tweet.

I have a different problem with the FTC settlement. It's that, by settling and not pursuing the company and bringing its practices into the light of day (Facebook is making no admissions), the government is permitting Facebook to obscure what its real agenda is, and that is to monetize user content, surreptitiously, in ways the average user would never approve.

The settlement is still a proposal, not a done deal, and I think it should not be approved.

The Kindle Fire is not a first generation product.

The Fire was never intended to be an iPad or any other tablet replacement or "killer." It was meant to be a bit of a spiffed-up e-Reader with a few other handy functions. Yes, it is not that smooth, but how many 1st generation products are? The first iPad wasn't that great, nor the first iPhone -- when compared to later editions.

Also, I am very surprised that neither the article nor any of the comments mention that you can password protect the Fire -- just like the iPad.

Though I am not thrilled with this initial version of Fire, I have no intention of returning it since it works well for me. I am absolutely confident that subsequent ones will be much improved. (Disclosure -- we are a "technophile" family with multiple devices and PCs/Macs).
"Down to" - ha.  I actually laughed sympathetically with that part of your comment.
Pay less to get less is exactly a smart option if you are getting what you want!  Love the Kindle Fire!

I for one certainly don't need more electronic junk around my house. My family is down to a Mac Pro, an iPhone 4s each, an Apple TV, and of course he iPad2. This combination covers all our communication, photographic, and gaming needs. Fun enough for everyone. Pay less to get less not the smart option. There is a reason why Apple is now fighting for most valuable corporation on Earth and it is top notch and elegant products. Love to buy stuff on Amazon with one click and Prime shipping but won't throw away dough fr inferior products to collect dust in a drawer somewhere.

Props to Mourinho for coming out to play. He had faith in his side, they were on a tremendous run of form, and he had them take the game to Barcelona. Just like last year going in to the Camp Nou.

Last May at Wembley, Manchester United attacked and pressed hard, and looked great against Barcelona. For about 10 minutes. Then Barca adjusted and it was game over. When you press hard, space opens up somewhere, the trick is to get players in those spaces and to find them under duress. That FCB do better than anyone. It took them 30 minutes and a scintillating Messi assist Saturday, because Madrid are much better than United, but once they did you never got the feeling Madrid were coming back. Yes, CR7 was wasteful, particularly on the header, and yes, Casillas was amazing. But those last 25 minutes were mostly keepaway and there was nothing Madrid could do. Even against what was by then a 3 man back line.

So far, if you're any good (ie, not a Hercules or Getafe) the only things that have worked have been to park the bus and counter, or play hack-and-slashball and drag them down to that level. But they seem to have figured out the latter, and since the CL match in Milan no one has gotten the former to work. Don't know what JM has to do at this point.

Watching the game with my friend from Barcelona (and my kid in the Messi jersey that my friend bought for him), he (my friend) kept saying "See, Barca is dominating the game." But of course, I said, they have possession, they have control, that's what they do. But at the same time, I noted, Real Madrid had far more chances than they have had in the past (just as another ball skittered across the front of the Barca goal with no one there to punch it in). Ultimately, I think that Real Madrid had more clear chances that Barca. But CR7 couldn't finish his two opportunities and others were missing the player to finish. The ultimate contrast was when CR7 whiffed on his header and then, moments later, Fabregas stuck his in the back of the net.

Are the teams that different in quality? I dunno, they play different styles. Barca does their ticky-tacky thing and Real Madrid looks to counter. But ultimately, I think that Barca has Real Madrid's number. The former finishes when they need to whereas the latter whiffs far too often given the chances that they do have. It can't just be a matter of skill because in most cases CR7 puts that cross in the back of the net.

I'm sorry your experience was frustrating, non-heavy e-reader,thanks for sharing, but the fire perfectly fits a range of needs (mainly reading, unfocussed browsing, and entertainment) that the nexus one and mywork environment cannot satisfy.

Euro-zone crisis may remain longer than Merkel and Sarkozy can imagine, from all the reports I have seen. UK's veto last week was a hollow gesture, since UK is not part of the euro-zone, though still in EU.

What's more worrisome is a growing interest in austerity, the measures taken or considered preferred. Not the right time.

Nothing wrong with being fiscally careful and remaining solvent, but when economy is in such a bad shape in Europe (as in the US and other places). austerity doesn't seem to be the best remedy for spurring growth: austerity measures undercut economic growth. UK under Cameron is going through the problems now.

The most worrisome thing I found in your piece is a tendency in some EU countries to return to more authoritarianism under such economic circumstances. Hungary is troubling, given its own history.

Are we going to see a slow but steady emergency of extremism there and spreading across Europe, not just limited to Euro-zone ? There's of course some resentment of stronger role of Germany, though France has been a moderating influence.

Looks like we are in for not just economic problems there but political too (growing authoritarian/extremist influence).

We, in the US, have to watch and learn, and be prepared. The 2012 election year will be difficult in the country, which is still lost in the economic woods,

A good sobering perspective!

Actually, my Finnish friend just ran across an English word he didn't know a few weeks back: "procrastination". When we explained the meaning, he said there was no corresponding word in Finnish. Now, that's no surprise. But what DID surprise us was that there's no corresponding CONCEPT in Finnish. It's not just that they use a phrase of words like "to stall in order to avoid unwanted work" to mean "procrastinate". They literally don't use the concept. My friend checked a Finnish/English dictionary and consulted several family members, and all agree with that.

So sometimes, concepts really DON'T exist in every language.

The non sequitir has an expressive power all its own. "...the Dothraki, with their long braids, or “jahaki,” wouldn’t have a word for toilet" is an image that will, unfortunately, stay with me well into the next season of Game of Thrones.

Speaking of thrones, what would Inuit linguists make of the astonishing number of slang terms and euphemisms for "toilet" in English? To see ourselves as others see us, indeed! (Which is of course one of many fine reasons to study languages whether natural or contrived. To know Klingon is to know Klingons, and doubtless safer.)

Perhaps they're just repeating the hoax for fun.

If the theory is correct, Dothraki must also have 14 words for pectorals, gratuitous nudity, and so on. Linguists should study this issue.

As a student of linguistics... this article makes me cringe quite a bit.

"Dothraki, with their long braids, or 'jahaki,' wouldn’t have a word for toilet, cellphone or even book since that implies they have a printing press. The Dothraki do however have more than 14 words for horse (including 'hrazefishi' for a teeny-tiny horse)."

If Mr. Peterson had studied linguistics, he would know that the Eskimo Snow Hoax has plagued us linguists long enough as it is! The ESH is basically the idea that eskimos, being surrounded by snow, must have more words for snow in their language, sometimes quoted at absurd numbers like 40-100. It is empirically false (google "The Great Eskimo Vocabulary Hoax" by Geoffrey K. Pullum) but has found a lasting home in folk wisdom/misinformation.

Furthermore, languages borrow or calque words all the time. So I am a bit disappointed that Mr. Peterson neglects to give the Dothraki any word for book, etc.

People have a strange fascination by what "words" make up a language. There are books about random words which exist supposedly in only one language for esoteric, culture bound concepts. But this is a fallacy. It might take longer to express a concept in one language or another, but all languages have basically equal expressive power.

I have been using the Fire since Nov 17 and love it! I don't seem to have all the problems that other complain about. I have a fast Verizon Fios web connection and the pages load nearly as fast as my laptop, including the full web versions not just mobile sites. I don't have any problems with the touchscreen performance and truthfully I don't need or want the majority of the apps available out there. Any that I did find I wanted that were not available I was able to find a comparable substitute that took care of my needs. I speak only for myself and for me it works and works very well. I don't think I will ever need to buy an Ipad.

I pre-ordered and still have my Amazon Fire in the box because I am still happily using my 3G Kindle to read free book samples. Most of my purchases, however, have been HB editions because there is so little price difference between that and the Kindle edition. At under $200, the Fire is worth it to have brighter pictures and color but not to buy more books, especially fiction. Does anyone believe, for example, that "Port Mortuary" and its new sequel are worth the price?

Overall, I don't like to pay more than $10 for the Kindle edition of a book, Fire or not! So, even though I will be buying more nonfiction HB books because of "Kindle exposure" to new titles, I will not be templed to build a personal library of e-Books.

Sorry, Mr. Bezo. This is not the same as buying Amy Winehouse's "REHAB" for $1.98 and enjoying it with sadness a dozen times on my smartphone. Does anyone ever read a book twice?

I will gladly pay $85 for a six-color set of Epson ink cartridges or $20 for a hardback from Amazon but take me off the list for eBooks books over 10 bucks. As my German friends used to say "Es nicht worse es."

My mother never bought sugary cereals for our family, except for one box per child during our annual vacation every year.  Similar junk foods were also extremely limited.  I never felt deprived because I learned early on that the sugary/salty/unhealthy foods did not make me feel good.  Beyond that, I learned that sugar was a very special treat to be consumed carefully.  In no small way, I am grateful to my mom for being strict because it taught my siblings and I to be equally as conscious about the foods we consume to nourish our bodies.  When I look at my close childhood friends who struggle with their weight and their ability to lead a healthful lifestyle, many had easy access to junk foods like sugary cereals.  Coincidence?  I think not.

I have to concur with the other comments that raise the question of why Mr. Tolkien's work is given so little attention in the article. His were likely the most robust fictional (i.e. created as part of a work of fiction) languages because they were accompanied by such a rich concept of their respective cultures. Without the latter, the history and etymologies that give a language life and make it truly believable are largely absent.

I don't think the appreciation of creative works is inconsistent with the recognition of social issues. If anything, the tendency for people to be drawn toward fictional languages such as Dothraki or Mr. Tolkien's Elvish tongues could be used as an avenue for opening discussion about the importance of preserving endangered languages and cultures. For many, social issues presented in a conventional manner would not otherwise draw as much interest.

My Kindle Fire has happily met my expectations because I was not expecting an i-Pad; I was expecting a much improved Kindle and that what I got. The Fire offers vastly improved graphics and much easier reading on my tired eyes.

As the first generation device, I knew there would be some shortcomings, but from what I've experienced so far, these can for the most part be addressed through software upgrades that will no doubt come along.

Amazon has always been attentive to their customers, so I look forward to future improvements. Otherwise, the bottom line is value for money. All things considered, the Fire is a good deal and importantly, I would have no reservations in recommending it to friends.
